original_data.question:
A mother brings her 18-year-old daughter to your office because she has not menstruated yet. They recently immigrated from another country, and do not have any previous medical records. The adolescent girl looks relatively short, but otherwise looks healthy. She has no complaints except for mild intermittent lower abdominal pain for the past year. On physical examination, vitals are within normal limits. There is the presence of axillary hair, breast development, and pubic hair at Tanner stage 5. You explain to the mother and the patient that you need to perform a complete vaginal examination, however, both of them declined the procedure and would prefer that lab test be performed. Her labs are significant for the following:
FSH 7 mIU/mL
Normal values:  
   Follicular phase 3.1 – 7.9 mIU/mL
   Ovulation peak 2.3 – 18.5 mIU/mL
   Luteal phase 1.4 – 5.5 mIU/mL
   Postmenopausal 30.6 – 106.3 mIU/mL
Estradiol 28 pg/mL
Normal values:  
   Mid-follicular phase 27 – 123 pg/mL
   Periovulatory 96 – 436 pg/mL
   Mid-luteal phase 49 – 294 pg/mL
   Postmenopausal 0 – 40 pg/mL
Testosterone 52 ng/dL, 40 – 60 ng/dL
What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?

model_response:
This patient has:

- Primary amenorrhea
- Normal secondary sexual characteristics
- Normal FSH
- Absent uterus on physical examination

Muellerian agenesis is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea. It is a congenital malformation resulting in a missing uterus and variable degrees of vaginal hypoplasia. It is the cause of approximately 10% of cases of primary amenorrhea. The incidence is approximately 1 in 1000 female births. The karyotype is 46, XX. Gonads are present, and ovaries are normal. The physical findings are a shoened or absent vagina in addition to absence of the uterus. Breast development and pubic hair development are normal.

Hyperprolactinemia is a cause of secondary amenorrhea. It results in anovulation and subsequent absence of estrogen withdrawal bleeding. Common causes of hyperprolactinemia include prolactinomas, medications, and chronic renal failure. Physical findings include galactorrhea and may include visual field abnormalities if a macroprolactinoma is present.

Turner syndrome is a genetic disorder that results in a missing X chromosome in phenotypic females (karyotype 45, XO). It is the cause of approximately 15% of cases of primary amenorrhea. Physical findings include short stature, webbed neck, low posterior hairline, shield-shaped chest, widening of long bones with the appearance of "coffee bean" osteoporosis, and streak ovaries with the absence of ovarian follicles.

Androgen insensitivity syndrome is a genetic disorder in which phenotypic females have a male karyotype (karyotype 46, XY). It is the cause of approximately 5% of cases of primary amenorrhea. Physical findings include absence of mullerian structures (uterus, cervix, and upper vagina), presence of testicular or ovarian structures, absence of breast development, and presence of pubic and axillary hair.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Female parents, human or animal.
Any doughnut-shaped device.
A female human offspring.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
Migration into a foreign country to live permanently there.

A collective generic term that refers here to a wide variety of dependencies, areas of special sovereignty, uninhabited islands, and other entities in addition to the traditional countries or independent states.
Recording of pertinent information concerning patient's illness or illnesses.
A person 13 to 18 years of age.
Having no significant health-related issues.
Periodically stopping and starting.
Sensation of discomfort, distress, or agony in the abdominal region.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A table of data specifically regarding vitals.
A bone that forms the lower and anterior part of each side of the hip bone.

A filament-like structure consisting of a shaft which projects to the surface of the SKIN from a root which is softer than the shaft and lodges in the cavity of a HAIR FOLLICLE. It is found on most surfaces of the body.

A scale of physical development in children, adolescents and adults based on external primary and secondary sex characteristics, such as the size of the breasts, genitalia, and development of pubic hair.
Female parents, human or animal.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.

Comprised of bimanual examination of the FEMALE GENITALIA performed as internal together with simultaneous external PALPITATION through the abdominal wall; speculum examination; CULPOSCOPY examination of cervix and vaginal wall epithelium; and VAGINAL SMEARS. (from Dictionary of Obstetrics and Gynecology)

An activity that produces an effect, or that is intended to alter the course of a disease in a patient or population. This is a general term that encompasses the medical, social, behavioral, and environmental acts that can have preventive, therapeutic, or palliative effects.
Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.
The outcome of a laboratory test.
The range or frequency distribution of a measurement in a population (of organisms, organs or things) that has not been selected for the presence of disease or abnormality.

The period of the MENSTRUAL CYCLE representing follicular growth, increase in ovarian estrogen (ESTROGENS) production, and epithelial proliferation of the ENDOMETRIUM. Follicular phase begins with the onset of MENSTRUATION and ends with OVULATION.
The discharge of an OVUM from a rupturing follicle in the OVARY.

The period in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE that follows OVULATION, characterized by the development of CORPUS LUTEUM, increase in PROGESTERONE production by the OVARY and secretion by the glandular epithelium of the ENDOMETRIUM. The luteal phase begins with ovulation and ends with the onset of MENSTRUATION.
After menopause.
The 17-beta-isomer of estradiol, an aromatized C18 steroid with hydroxyl group at 3-beta- and 17-beta-position. Estradiol-17-beta is the most potent form of mammalian estrogenic steroids.
The range or frequency distribution of a measurement in a population (of organisms, organs or things) that has not been selected for the presence of disease or abnormality.

The period of the MENSTRUAL CYCLE representing follicular growth, increase in ovarian estrogen (ESTROGENS) production, and epithelial proliferation of the ENDOMETRIUM. Follicular phase begins with the onset of MENSTRUATION and ends with OVULATION.

The period in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE that follows OVULATION, characterized by the development of CORPUS LUTEUM, increase in PROGESTERONE production by the OVARY and secretion by the glandular epithelium of the ENDOMETRIUM. The luteal phase begins with ovulation and ends with the onset of MENSTRUATION.
After menopause.

A potent androgenic steroid and major product secreted by the LEYDIG CELLS of the TESTIS. Its production is stimulated by LUTEINIZING HORMONE from the PITUITARY GLAND. In turn, testosterone exerts feedback control of the pituitary LH and FSH secretion. Depending on the tissues, testosterone can be further converted to DIHYDROTESTOSTERONE or ESTRADIOL.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
